verses.text: A prayer of Habakkuk the prophet, according to Shigionoth.
verses.comment: The word 'Shigionoth' here refers to a musical or poetic form, used in liturgical worship, reminding the reader of the importance of prayerful songs in communal worship (see also Psalm 7).

verses.text: LORD, I have heard the report about you; I stand in awe, LORD, of your deeds. In the midst of the years revive them; in the midst of the years make them known; in wrath remember mercy.
verses.comment: Habakkuk acknowledges God's mighty acts and pleads for mercy in the midst of deserved judgement. The prophet's prayer reflects a pattern also seen in Moses and the psalmists who ask God to show steadfast love while executing justice.

verses.text: God came from Teman, and the Holy One from Mount Paran. Selah. His glory covered the heavens, and the earth was full of his praise.
verses.comment: This recalls God's appearance at Sinai, connecting the past salvation of Israel to future hope. The word Selah suggests a pause for contemplation, signifying the power of this theophany.

verses.text: His brightness was like the light; rays flashed from his hand, and there his power was hidden.
verses.comment: The divine radiance speaks of God's glory—visible yet mysterious. This language echoes images of Christ's Transfiguration, where his divine glory is revealed (see Mark 9; Ex. 34).

verses.text: Before him went pestilence, and plague followed at his heels.
verses.comment: God’s judgments are powerful and unstoppable, as seen in the Exodus plagues. This underlines the seriousness of sin and God's authority over all creation.

verses.text: He stood and measured the earth; he looked and shook the nations. Then the ancient mountains were scattered; the everlasting hills sank. His ways are everlasting.
verses.comment: God’s eternal and unchanging nature outlasts even the oldest hills. This reveals that God’s plan encompasses all history and all nations, highlighting divine sovereignty.

verses.text: I saw the tents of Cushan in distress; the curtains of the land of Midian trembled.
verses.comment: The fear of God’s judgment extends to distant nations. Even those not among Israel recognize the might of God—his works are universal.

verses.text: Was your wrath against the rivers, LORD? Was your anger against the rivers, or your fury against the sea, that you rode on your horses, on your chariots of salvation?
verses.comment: The poetic questions recall God’s miraculous deliverance of Israel, especially through water (Red Sea, Jordan). God’s victory imagery points to his role as divine warrior and savior.

verses.text: Your bow was made bare; you called for many arrows. Selah. You split the earth with rivers.
verses.comment: God's readiness for battle and command over creation are emphasized as proofs of his power. Selah invites further meditation on these mighty acts.

verses.text: The mountains saw you and writhed; the raging waters swept by; the deep roared and lifted its waves on high.
verses.comment: Creation responds in awe to God's presence. Such theophanic images are common in the psalms and point to God as the Lord over nature, a theme fulfilled in Christ calming the storm (see Mark 4:39).

verses.text: The sun and moon stood still in their habitation, at the light of your arrows as they sped, at the flash of your gleaming spear.
verses.comment: This recalls Joshua’s victory, emphasizing God's direct intervention in history. Such miracles point toward a God who acts physically and sacramentally, shaping time and events according to his will.

verses.text: In wrath you marched through the earth; in anger you threshed the nations.
verses.comment: God is depicted as a righteous judge, vindicating his people and punishing the wicked—anticipating Christ as the Lord who will judge the nations (Matthew 25:31-46).

verses.text: You went out for the salvation of your people, for the salvation of your anointed. You crushed the head of the house of the wicked, laying him bare from thigh to neck. Selah.
verses.comment: God acts for the salvation of both Israel and his 'anointed one', a term pointing to the Messiah. The defeat of the wicked head echoes protoevangelium in Genesis, prefiguring Christ’s ultimate victory over evil.

verses.text: With his own weapons you pierced the head of his warriors, who came like a whirlwind to scatter me, rejoicing as if to devour the poor in secret.
verses.comment: The imagery recalls God turning the weapons of the wicked against themselves. God defends the poor and downtrodden, a recurring biblical theme fulfilled in Christ who identifies with the weak.

verses.text: You trod the sea with your horses, through the swirling mighty waters.
verses.comment: God's sovereignty over chaotic waters is an Exodus image, but it also foreshadows Christ’s authority over the sea and his miraculous works (see Matthew 14:25).

verses.text: I heard and my body trembled; my lips quivered at the sound; decay entered my bones, and I trembled where I stood. Yet I wait quietly for the day of distress to come upon the people who invade us.
verses.comment: Habakkuk’s physical fear demonstrates awe in the presence of God’s judgment, but also his choice to wait faithfully for God’s deliverance—a model for perseverance in hope.

verses.text: Even though the fig tree does not bud, nor is there fruit on the vines, though the olive crop fails and the fields produce no food, though the sheep disappear from the fold and there are no cattle in the stalls—
verses.comment: This verse lists the total loss of material blessings, yet foreshadows faith in the unseen. True worship is not dependent on prosperity, a principle seen also in the lives of the saints.

verses.text: Yet I will rejoice in the LORD; I will be joyful in God my Savior.
verses.comment: Despite loss and hardship, the prophet resolves to rejoice in God alone, who is the source of salvation. This spirit is echoed by Mary in the Magnificat (Luke 1:47) and finds fulfillment in the joyful hope of the Church.

verses.text: The LORD God is my strength; he makes my feet like a deer’s; he enables me to tread on the high places. For the choirmaster, with stringed instruments.
verses.comment: Habakkuk closes in praise, relying on God’s strength rather than his own. The musical note at the end suggests this is a song for public worship, reflecting the ancient practice of liturgical music. This points to the power of communal worship in sustaining faith.
